text: James Howard "Jim" Vance III (January 10, 1942 â€“ July 22, 2017) was an American television news anchor in Washington, D.C.. In 1972, Vance became WRC-TV's main co-anchor, as one of the first African Americans to serve in this position at any American television station.Carmody, John. "WRC: Vance In, Boggs Out". The Washington Post. March 21, 1972. p. B4. Between 1972 and 1976, Vance worked as co-anchor with Glenn Rinker at WRC-TV."Glenn Rinker, 59, Dies; Was WRC-TV Anchor From '69 to Mid-1970s". The Washington Post. February 20, 1993. p. D7. Between 1976 and 1980, Vance co-anchored with Sue Simmons, a pairing that resulted in one of the first, if not the first, African-American co-anchors of a major market newscast. Vance died on July 22, 2017 in Washington, D.C. following a short battle with non-Hodgkin lymphoma at the age of 75.Bradford, Jackie. "News4 Anchor Jim Vance Dies at 75". WRC-TV. July 22, 2017. Retrieved July 22, 2017. At the time of his death, Vance was the region's longest-serving television news anchor with more than 45 years at WRC-TV. ==References== Category:1942 births Category:2017 deaths Category:Deaths from lymphoma Category:Cancer deaths in Washington, D.C.
